titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. The Senate adjourn’d over this day— With Mrs: Johnson and the three girls, I paid the customary visit to the President. His Rooms were very much crowded— The most distinguished visitors were a number of Indians—Osages—and a Mandan chief with two women, and three children.— The Mandan is much whiter than any of the Indians with whom we have been acquainted— And lighter than the ordinary complexion of a Spaniard or Italian. I pass’d the remainder of the day at home. Began the Copy of my sixteenth Lecture— Wrote to my wife— And read as usual in the Greek Odyssey and the English Bible.

2. On going to the Capitol this morning I received a letter from my wife, which gave me great anxiety for my eldest child who was very unwell— Mr: Bradley’s bill for the relief of Seth Harding was taken up, and postponed, for the report of the Commissioners of the Navy Pension fund— Mr: Clay the new member from Kentuckey moved for a Committee to report whether the Circuit Jurisdiction of the U.S. Supreme Court should be extended to the States of Kentuckey, Tennessee and Ohio— Motion to lay untill Monday. Senate adjourned before 1.— I went into the lobby of the House and heard a debate on a Report for a bill to relieve A. Benezet. Evening at home— Writing.

3. I called this morning to return the visits of Mr: Tayloe and Mr: Cutts—neither of whom was at home— Saw Mrs: Tayloe; and found there Dr: Jones and Mr: Blodget— In the Evening Captain Landais called upon me, and sat here half an hour— Mr: Sheldon was here the remainder of the Evening— By these interruptions I was prevented from writing as much as usual.

4. In the morning I heard Mr: Laurie at the Treasury; and in the Evening went with the three girls to the methodist Meeting. Mr: and Mrs: Boyd dined with us— My time was accordingly so much engaged that I wrote very little this day; and the lecture upon which I am now occupied drags very heavily along— We met Mr: Ripley at the Meeting—he came with us home; and sat here some time— I have no letters from Boston since Friday Morning.

5. Received this morning a letter from my wife, which relieved my extreme anxiety on account of George— I wrote a long letter to my brother, which detained me late at the Capitol— The Potowmac Bridge Bill was called up, and postponed untill this day week. Evening in my chamber, writing with much difficulty.

6. The only business done in Senate was, to raise a Committee upon a private petition— Adjourned before one O’Clock— I was however kept at the Capitol untill 3. writing to Mrs: Adams— Evening in my chamber, where my occupation was desultory; and almost entirely diverted from my lecture.

7. Continued writing what I began yesterday— Met in Committee Mr: Clay, Mr: Bradley and Mr: Baldwin; on the proposition for constituting a Judicial Circuit of the U.S. Courts in the three Western States— Mr: Giles was of the Committee, but did not attend.— Still very little business done in Senate.— On my way home, I called at Mr. Boyd’s— Resumed again the writing of my lecture, in the Evening.

8. Bill for relief of George Little, at the second reading committed to 3.— Bill for a new Coinage at second reading— Adjourn’d soon after 12. I went into the House of Representatives, and heard a question taken to recommit the negro-bill, so called, to a committee of 7. Also part of a debate on the bill to relieve A. Benezet.— Dined, and spent part of the Evening at Mr. Boyd’s— Mrs: Johnson and the young Ladies went to the Assembly— On returning home I finished the copy of my 16th: Lecture; and also the verses I have been writing to Mrs: Hellen— My lectures after this, will I fear repose, during the remainder of this Session— I received letters from my wife, and my brother.

9. Attended in Senate, where I can scarcely tell what was done— Adjourned before 1.— I wrote to my wife— After the adjournment attended Mr: Maclay and Mr: Tracy on the bill for relief of George Little; which we agreed to report, without Amendment.— This made it late before I left the Capitol— Evening in my chamber—occupation various—

10. The Senate did not sit this day— Visit from Mr: Stedman, Mr: Pitken, and Mr: Ripley— I returned Genl: Turreau’s visit but he was not at home— Call’d at Mr: Boyd’s— His child is yet very ill— I sent to Mrs: Hellen the lines I have written to her.— I was in the Evening at Mr: Madison’s; a large company there— Cards with Mr: Jackson, Mr: Turner and Mr: Cutts—and afterwards with Mrs: Mason, Mrs: Jackson, and Mr: Lee.

11. Heard Mr: Sayrs at Georgetown— It was a charity Sermon; and occasional, though I know not exactly upon what occasion— Mr: Addison read prayers— I dined with Mrs: Johnson & Mr: Hellen at Mr: Boyd’s— Mr: Caldwell was there also.— This Evening was also of course abstracted from all domestic occupation.

12. The Potowmac Bridge Bill excites more interest in this neighbourhood than all the other business in which Congress have been this Session engaged. It has been twice postponed before; and this day was again adjourned untill next Monday— Mr: Bayard took his Seat in Senate— The first time this Session— The bill to relieve George Little was reported by the Committee without amendment; consideration postponed untill to-morrow— The Judges of the Circuit Court, Columbia District reported to the Senate a fee-bill, according to the resolve of 14. April last—which was referred to a Committee of three— Adjourned before 1.— I wrote to Mr. Cleland and to Jacob Welsh— Mr: Johnson, & the girls dined abroad— Evening in my own chamber.

13. The first debate we have had in Senate this Session occurred, upon the Bill to relieve George Little; which however pass’d to the third reading by a considerable majority.— I took part in this debate without being sufficiently prepar’d, and therefore with little effect— My deficiencies were amply supplied, by Messrs: Bayard, Giles, Hillhouse and S. Smith— The opposition was very feeble, from Messrs: Maclay, Worthington and Smith of Vermont— We have symptoms of commencing business, and shall soon be much occupied— Evening in my chamber— Began the fair copy of my Lecture 17.

14. The Bill for the relief of George Little, pass’d, without a division— Some further documents and papers respecting the proposed Potowmac Bridge, were read and ordered to be printed— Not however without opposition; and by a bare majority of votes— Met two Committees; that on Mr: Clay’s motion for adding another Circuit to the U.S. Courts, and appointing an additional judge of the Supreme Court—and that on the Columbia District fee-bill; on both Committees we agreed to make Report.— I called at Mr: Boyd’s this morning. His child continues ill— Saw Judge Cushing, who arrived last Evening— I spent this Evening again in my chamber—

15. Called at the Bank as I went to the Capitol—received the dividend for N. Blanchard, and wrote to him enclosing a check on the Branch Bank, Boston, for the amount— The slave Bill which originated in Senate was discussed in Committee of the whole and occasioned a long debate— Mr: Clay the new Member from Kentucky made an ardent Speech upon one of the Sections— He is quite a young Man—an Orator—and a Republican of the first fire— I took and intend to take no part in the debates on this subject— I reported the Columbia District fee-bill which pass’d to the second reading— Several other Reports were made, and from this day I date the commencement of serious business in Senate for the present Session— Adjourned after 3— Evening in my chamber, labouring heavily and tediously.

16. Stopp’d at Mr: Boyd’s on my way to the Capitol— His child continues ill— The debate on the Slave-bill was renewed, and continued untill past 3. O’Clock, without coming to any question— The Bill for raising an additional Regiment of troops pass’d without a division. Mr: Moore and Mr: Giles presented some Resolutions from the State of Virginia, having a view to the removal of their free Blacks from the State— They are to lay over untill Monday.— I rode with Mr: Giles on his way home, to the Bridge of Georgetown— Evening in my chamber again, groping as I have done for this whole week, on a dark passage in my Course of Lectures.

17. Dined at Genl: Mason’s in Georgetown, with a company consisting principally of members of Congress— Mrs: Duvall, Mrs: Jackson and Mrs: Cutts, were the only Ladies, except Miss Murray, Mrs: Mason’s Sister— Mrs: Mason herself was unwell, and did not appear untill the Evening; when the Company became numerous— I wasted it at Cards— Came home with Mrs: Johnson, and the young Ladies— Received letters from my wife and father.— I employed the morning upon my lecture; through which I begin to perceive a glimpse of light— But I lost more than half the day and of course accomplished not more than half my daily task.

18. Snow all the morning— I attended therefore at the Methodist Meeting as the nearest place of Worship; but did not hear their most eloquent Speaker— Remainder of the day at home, and toiled very assiduously upon my lecture—

19. On attending in Senate this morning, I found them just going upon the consideration of the Potowmac Bridge Bill— It employed all the remainder of the day untill near 4. O’Clock— Mr: Giles in a long and very able argument opposed the passage of the bill.— Mr: Boyd and Mr: Templeman were below the whole Evening; so that I wrote nothing.

20. The Potowmac Bridge Bill again occupied the Senate the whole day— Mr: White in a very elegant Speech, and Mr: Moore in a speech of not much force, supported the Bill— Upon which Genl: Smith of Maryland, and Mr: Giles again replied. I spent the Evening at home, in arranging my thoughts on the subject with a view to speak concerning it to-morrow—

21. The whole day was employed in debating on the receipt or rejection of several Certificates from members of the House of Representatives, which were finally received, by the casting vote of the Vice-President— I took some part in this debate— As I was going home the Vice-President took me in his carriage— He was going to dine at the President’s— I left him there— In the Evening I went with the Ladies to Miss Lee’s at Georgetown, where we spent the Evening— I played again at Cards, an amusement which has become to my taste a toil, but to which at these parties I am driven from a want of light conversation.

22. Met the Committee on the internal sedition Bill. Mr: Giles, Tracy, Stone, Mitchill and myself—all present— We came to no final determination— Senate were engaged again all day upon the Bridge Bill; with an interval of half an hour to read a Message from the President respecting Burr’s conspiracy.— Mr: Maclay and myself spoke in opposition to the Bill. Mr: Clay in its favour— I think it will certainly pass— Senate adjourn’d without taking the question— I spoke about an hour; but the subject had been exhausted by Mr: Giles— And I could only present some of his ideas in New Lights— I should have done better to remain silent— My defects of Elocution are incurable, and amidst so many better Speakers, when the debates are to be reported, I never speak without mortification— The process of reasoning in my mind is too slow for uninterrupted articulation— My thoughts arise at first, confused and require time, to shape into a succession of Sentences— Hence the transition from thought to thought is aukward and inelegant; and expression often fails me to accomplish a sentence commenced; so that I often begin a thought with Spirit and finish it with nonsense— The chain of my Argument often escapes me, and when lost can seldom be retrieved— I then finish as I can, without producing half the arguments I proposed before I began to speak— These faults would be so overpowering that I should sink into perpetual silence, from mere impotence, were it not that some times in the ardour of debate, when my feelings are wound up to a high tone, elocution pours itself along with unusual rapidity; and I have passages, which would not shame a good Speaker; this is the only thing that makes me tolerable to others or to myself— Evening at home— The Ladies went to the Ball.

23. On going to the Senate this morning, I was informed that Mr: Jonn: Mason of Boston, who is here, and who was present yesterday at the debate in Senate, had denied the accuracy of some of my Statements afterwards at dinner where Mr: Clay was present— I had no time to enquire further into this subject, for immediately on the meeting of the Senate, Mr: Giles moved that the galleries should be cleared; and then a Resolution for a Committee to bring in a Bill, to suspend for a limited time the privilege of the Writ of Habeas Corpus.— Mr: Bayard made some objections to the measure, and finally moved an amendment to the Resolution, directing the Committee to enquire into the expediency of the suspension with leave to Report by Bill or otherwise. Mr: Giles after some discussion consented that the question should be put in the form proposed by Mr: Bayard— It then pass’d without a division— The Committee were appointed— Mr: Giles, Mr: Smith of Maryland, and myself— They had leave to sit immediately, and while Senate were in Session— We examined some English Books for precedents, but could not find any; the English Statutes for this purpose being all temporary, and not included in the Statutes at Large— Mr: Giles drew a short Bill, which the Committee agreed immediately to report, with a confidential message, which I drew, to send with the Bill to the House of Representatives.— The Bill was by unanimous consent read three times, and with amendments proposed by Mr: Bayard and Mr: Hillhouse, pass’d; Mr: Bayard only voting against it— But he candidly wav’d the privilege of preventing its being read three times on the same day— The Message was agreed to, and Mr: Smith of Maryland appointed a Committee to carry the Bill and Message to the House— They however had adjourned. It was half past four when the Senate adjourned over to Monday— I pass’d the Evening in my chamber, but my mind is now so engross’d with public business that I can attend to nothing else.

24. I attended this morning on three Committees at the Capitol— On the bill for the punishment of certain Crimes against U.S—on the bill for surveying the Coasts, and on the Bill supplementary to that for the payment of the whole Public Debt. A Report was agreed to, for amendments to the second of these— The other two did not come to any decision— I called upon Mr
Mr: Pickering and Mr: S. Smith to enquire, what Mr: Mason had said to which they referr’d yesterday, and found that it was little more than an expression of dissatisfaction at my Speech, which he thought weak, and in substance favourable to the side which I opposed— Mr: Giles brought me from the Capitol, nearly home— I dined at Mr: Erskine’s; in Company with ten or twelve members of Congress— All federals— Spent the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s.

25. I attended Church at the Capitol, and heard Mr: Elliot— Afterwards called upon Judge Cushing and his Lady at Stelle’s— Met there Coll: T. H. Perkins and Mr: I. P. Davis— I then went to Mr: Cranch’s; where I dined and pass’d the Evening— Judge Cushing and his Lady—Mr: and Mrs: Brent.—Mr: I. P. Davis and Mr: Dwight were there— Mr: Cranch brought me home, late in the Evening.

26. As soon as the House of Representatives received the message from the Senate with the Bill suspending the Privilege of the Writ of Habeas Corpus, they immediately opened their doors, and after a short debate rejected it almost unanimously at the first reading— The bills for the relief of S. Harding, and for establishing an additional Circuit to the Courts of the United States pass’d the Senate— The debate on the Bill to prohibit the importation of Slaves was resumed, but seemed to have lost all its Interest— The amendments which had been so warmly agitated were this day rejected after very little said—no comment was made upon any other part of the bill, which pass’d to a third reading without a division— I spent part of the Evening in my chamber, and part below, where was Mr: Sheldon.

27. Attended this morning the Committee, on the financeering Bill— Mr: Gallatin the Secretary of the Treasury was there; who gave some explanations on particular Sections of the Bill— We agreed to report it without amendment— Mr: Gallatin informed us that a part of the 3d: Section of a bill pass’d the last Session of Congress (Chap: 50) was inserted by mistake, on the enrollment; and had been signed by the President as part of the Law though it had been an amendment first introduced by the Senate and finally receded from— In Senate they tried to produce a debate on some bill, other than that for the Potowmac Bridge, but could not— The Slave-Prohibition bill pass’d without a division, and several others without debate— The Bridge-bill was finally taken up— Mr: Thruston moved its postponement till next Session, which occasioned a debate of 3 hours— Mr: Moore made a speech against postponement which he concluded by saying he should vote for it— Adjourned a little before 4 O’Clock without taking the question— Mr: Bayard is yet to speak.

28— After examining a long bill on the Committee of engross’d Bills, I found on entering the Senate the debate on the Bridge bill, opened by Mr: Smith of Vermont, who read several affidavits respecting the situation of the Bridge at Cork in Ireland, upon which he made a few observations— Mr: Bayard in a Speech of three hours opposed the postponement, and advocated the Bridge.— Genl: Smith shortly answered some of his remarks and he replied— It was past 3. O’Clock and Mr: Tracy ask’d for an adjournment, declaring his intention to speak upon the question— The Senate accordingly adjourned— Mr: Bayard’s Speech consisted altogether of answers to the objections made by Genl: Smith, Mr: Giles and myself— His fluency is inexhaustible— He speaks with so much ease, that he is never for an instant embarrass’d himself; nor suffers his hearers to be embarrass’d for him.— His reasoning is clear, forcible, and overflowing with illustration.— But he is sometimes indiscreet by hazarding insinuations which he cannot support, and his moral and political knowledge is not very profound— His style is plain to a degree of dryness— Evening at home— In the morning I had accompanied Catherine to Mr: Boyd’s & to Mrs: Madison’s.

29. The question upon the postponement of the Potowmack Bridge bill, was finally taken this day after 3. O’Clock, and carried, by yeas and nays 17 to 16. Mr: Tracy made a handsome speech in favour of the postponement— Mr: Milledge, Mr: Bradley and Mr: Clay spoke against it— After the adjournment I went into the Court house, and heard part of an argument by Mr: Jones the District Attorney, on a motion for the commitment of the two State prisoners Bollman and Swartwout— Spent the Evening at Mr: Erskine’s; but it was late before we went— Miss Keene, a lady from Philadelphia was there, with her Sister Mrs: Lenox, and entertained the company by her performance on the Tambourine.

30. The argument on the motion to commit Bollman and Swartwout was this day concluded by the Attorney General Mr. Rodney; and they were committed as on a charge of high treason. The house of Representatives were not able to make a quorum, and adjourned without one— Many of the members were attending as Spectators in the Court-house.—
I did not think proper however to leave my duty in the Senate for that purpose. We pass’d two or three bills, and could not raise a debate untill the Columbia District fee-bill came on, which was taken up as in Committee of the whole, and after much nibbling opposition from Mr: Bayard, Mr: Hillhouse, and Mr: Bradley, (who was on the Committee which reported the Bill, and had there agreed to it) finally pass’d to the third reading.— I moved a Resolution for adding a new Rule to the Rules for conducting business in Senate; which lies for consideration.— Adjourned after 3.— Spent the Evening in Company at Mr: Madison’s; principally at Cards— Mr: Madison mentioned that the Negotiations of our Ministers in England were suspended, on a difficulty respecting the point of impressments—

31. I attended at the Capitol on a Committee with Mr: Giles and Mr: Bayard, upon the President’s last Messages respecting Burr’s conspiracy— Mr: Rodney the Attorney General was there— We came to no final determination; but agreed in the opinion that Bollman and Swartwout cannot be tried here.— Heavy Rain all day— Mr: Giles took me home— He is as communicative as ever of opinions respecting persons, and express’d himself in terms of no great respect, concerning the Vice-President, Mr: Clinton— He said that if his friends had sent him here with a view to push him on to the Presidency they had been unlucky in the choice of their expedient— It was a dangerous experiment, to send a man to Congress with views to such advancement—for in such conspicuous Stations a man was apt to be seen through— He instanced particularly in the case of Mr: Thomas Pinckney; who was sent to Congress after being voted for as President, but was never voted for as President after being sent to Congress— Then they took up his brother C. C. Pinckney; and if they had sent him to Congress they would soon have discovered that he was as ill-qualified for the Presidency as Thomas— He also talk’d much of Burr, whose principles had always been suspicious to him— Wade Hampton, and a Mr: Hunter of S. Carolina, whom he call’d a two-fisted Irishman were in his opinion mere tools of Burr— He intimated that Burr had endeavoured also to make him one of his instruments, but had failed— He spoke favourably of E. Livingston’s talents, and told me of a project they had formed at the time of the British Treaty to impeach Mr: Jay— From the openness with which Giles talks of persons and the freedoms he takes with characters I think he must have many inveterate enemies— I dined at General Turreau’s, with a company of about twenty members of Congress— Sitting at table next to Mr: Bayard he gave me his opinion of Mr: Giles— It was that of a rival, and I think too acrimonious— He thinks him timid, vindictive, and unrestrained by principle— Evening at home.

Day. Rise about 7. Read Homer untill 9. Breakfast— Walk to the Capitol— Attend in Senate untill 3. or 4. Walk home. Dine— Spend the Evening usually in my chamber untill 9 or 10.— The first three weeks of this month I continued engaged upon my lectures— But since then I have pass’d several Evenings in Company abroad, and have been employed when at home in examining papers and reflecting on the public business before Congress— Literary pursuits require a mind at leisure. I have this day finished the perusal of Homer’s Odyssey in the Original; which with the aid of the Latin side version, and of Pope’s translation I understand tolerably well.— The latter books however, I must read over again, for while perusing them my mind has been too rambling, and my application not sufficiently under my own controul.
